PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: AMP Capital (AMP AT) CEO Meller to resign with immediate effect
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP Capital (AMP AT)
- Co. CEO Meller is to resign with immediate effect, while Co. plans to make submission to the Royal Commission to respond to issues. (Newswires)

APN Outdoor (APO AT)
- Co. reports April YTD trading is inline with company forecasts. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT)
- Co. CEO reportedly raised questions regarding the future of its Australian franchise business model. (The Australian)

Evolution Mining (EVN AT)
- Shareholder La Mancha Group offers 84.5mln Evolution Mining shares in private placement at AUD 3.19-3.33 vs. last close AUD 3.36 per share. (Newswires)

Macquarie (MQG AT)
- Co. led consortium was among the parties that submitted bids for Gas Pipeline Company from Petrobras. (Newswires)

Sydney Airport (SYD AT)
- Co. March traffic rose 6.1% Y/Y, while international traffic was up 11.1% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Financials
- Australia’s largest banks are reportedly set to sign off on a combined profit of over AUD 13bln. (The Australian)
- Large banks could face maximum fines of AUD 210mln or be fined 10% of annual revenue, according to reports.  (The Australian)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Iron ore rose nearly 4%.
- WTI crude futures pulled back to test USD 68/bbl to the downside.

 

JAPAN

Daikyo (8840 JT)
- Co. raises FY17/18 oper. profit forecast to JPY 20.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 19.0bln. (Newswires)

FamilyMart Uny Holdings (8028 JT)
- Itochu (8001 JT) is seeking to spend JPY 120bln to increase its stake in Co. to 50.1% from around 41.5%. (Newswires)

Takeda (4502 JT)
- Co. offer for Shire (SHP LN) of GBP 46.50/Shr was rejected as it was said to undervalue the Co. (Newswires)

Tokyo Tatemono (8804 JT)
- Co. is to build 2 high-rise condominiums in Bangkok as part of its expansion into the Thailand market. (Nikkei)

Toshiba (6502 JT)
- Chief of SK Hynix which is part of the consortium to buy Co. memory chip business says the deal is likely to be settled soon. (Newswires)

Other News
- US President Trump is said to see large sales of arms as a quick solution for the Japan trade deficit, while he also said to be seeking concessions on cars and beef. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Court accepted Co. request to temporarily suspends disclosure of reports related to workplace environment until a verdict is made regarding lawsuit between Co. and government. (Yonhap)

SK Hynix (000660 KS)
- Co. chief says deal to acquire Toshiba memory chip business in which it is part of the consortium with Bain Capital, is likely to be settled soon. (Yonhap)

Other News
- South Korea and North Korea will open a direct telephone line between the 2 nations’ leaders today ahead of summit next week. (Newswires)
- North Korea no longer seeks the withdrawal of US forces in the peninsula as a condition for denuclearization. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury is weighing emergency powers regarding China, according to a US official. (Newswires)

Chinese president XI said they will continue to support free trade system and safeguard the multilateral trade system. (Newswires)


UK

EU said to reject the UK’s Brexit Irish border solution as doubts grow over whether UK can leave customs union. (Newswires)

BoE's Governor Carney said to prepare for a number of interest hikes for the next few years, although he added that he does not want to get too focused on timing and that the path is more important. Furthermore, Carney acknowledged mixed data and said there will likely be differences of views on MPC at May meeting, while he also noted that MPC is conscious that there are other meetings over the course of this year and that wage growth and productivity require improvement. (Newswires)

BoE’s Cunliffe (Dove) expressed warning on trade and stated that tensions could spill over into other areas. (Newswires)

UK Retail Sales MM (Mar) -1.2% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)
UK Retail Sales YY (Mar) 1.1% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.5%)


EU

German Finance Minister Scholz said Germany is seeking a permanent exemption on US steel duties, while he added that Germany and France will not seek a special trade deal with the US. (Newswires)

Italy’s Northern League’s Leader Salvini wants to discuss a government plan with 5SM. (Newswires)


FX

An all too familiar story for the Greenback with several attempts to rally and the DXY up to 89.700+ at one stage, but the broad Dollar unable to extend or sustain gains and ultimately fading. GBP Not quite zero to hero, but a sterling effort by the Pound given triple dose of disappointing data this week. Cable initially extended its reversal from new post-Brexit vote high (around 1.4375) to circa 1.4160 on a bad retail sales miss, but is back above 1.4200 and looking to close over the 200 HMA at 1.4225 to resume its April rally. However, after the gilt market close, comments from BoE’s Governor Carney put a downward bias into sterling, with some interpreting his comments as a suggestion that the May hike was not a dead-cert. NZDAUD The Kiwi is losing grip of the 0.7300 handle vs the Usd after Q1 CPI slowed markedly in y/y terms to 1.1% and further below the RBNZ’s 2% target, while its antipodean peer is holding up better, but recoiling from another advance above 0.7800 in wake of downbeat Aussie employment data, both in headline and full time placement terms. JPY/EUR/CAD All locked in tight confines, with USDJPY absorbing some exporter offers around 107.50, but not all and finding plenty of support ahead of 107.00, while EURUSD pivoted 1.2375 between a 1.2400-1.2350 band and USDCAD saw similar price action either side of 1.2600 even though Canada’s ADP was strong and there was more good news on NAFTA negotiations (telecoms chapter reportedly settled to take the tally to 11). USDCHF popped above 0.9700, and arguably around the time that EURCHF touched 1.2000 (depending on what price feed or platform is referenced), before relative sharp retracements in both pairs. Note, however, one of the prominent Swiss banks is looking for further Franc depreciation. USDRUB, USDTRY and USDMXN saw more lively price action, with the Rouble underpinned within 60.5000-61.2000 trading parameters amidst the ongoing crude oil rally and the Lira extending its recovery to almost 4.0000 before losing some impetus, but the Peso handing back more gains from sub-18.0000 levels on a wave of Mexican political jitters.


COMMODITIES

According to an OPEC delegate there was no talk from the Saudis to target USD 100/bbl and that USD 100 target is a danger to the market, while there were also comments from the Oman Oil Minister that USD 65-75/bbl is a realistic oil price range. (Newswires)

OPEC sources noted Iraq is still cheating on set quota. (Newswires)


US

US Deputy AG Rosenstein reportedly told President Trump he is not target of investigation of Michael Cohen. In related news, President Trump was said to tell associates he will not remove Special Counsel Mueller, while there were also separate reports that House Republicans are said to lay the groundwork for Trump to fire Rosenstein. (Newswires/NY Mag)

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dovish) said inflation is well anchored bet there are some signs of imbalances. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures trended lower through Thursday trade printing lows beneath 2685, however in late trade reports suggested US Deputy AG Rosenstein told US President Trump that he is not going to be a target of a probe. Further, Trump said he will not remove special counsel Mueller which gave a lift to Emini futures testing the 2700 level. Pre-market trade on Thursday saw a heavy dose of M&A news; focus was on Shire (SHPG) / (SHP LN) as Takeda (4502 JT) made a new offer of £46.50/shr but it was rejected by the pharmaceutical company; further source reports suggested it was to have two others bidding for the company, in which Allergan (AGN) came out noting they were in early acquisition talks, but the final source reports told CNBC that AGN would not be making a bid, which was then later on confirmed, but Allergan did note they’re continuing to evaluate strategic options. Further, Comcast (CMCSA) sent a bid for Fox’s Assets, higher than Disney’s (DIS) offer, however CNCB notes the conditions were not favourable and were said to raise regulatory concerns. Elsewhere, reports In NY Post stated that the US DoJ is said to be close to clearing the $6.6bln Sinclair (SBGI) & Tribune Media (TRCO) merger. Semiconductor names were in focus today following poor outlook from Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC) which expects Q2 revenue to be between $7.8bln and $7.9bln, roughly $1bln lower than wall street estimates. This had a knock-on effect to other chipmakers with the SOX spending the session in the red and chip names all at the bottom of the NDX. Also, reports just before the close yesterday that Facebook (FB) is said to create a team to create semiconductors also hampered some names like Intel (INTC). Elsewhere in stock specifics earnings dominated yet again, with Snap-On (SNA), American Express (AXP) Bank of New York Mellon among top performers in the SPX following strong earnings report. On the flipside Phillip Morris (PM) getting smoked following a miss on revenues and a larger decline than expected in cigarette and heated tobacco shipments, this rolled on to Altria (MO) also closing among the worst SPX performers.  SPX -0.59% at 2693, NDX -0.86% at 6774, DJI -0.34% at 24664.

The yield curve bear-flattened on Thursday with most of the action seen in the long-end, where 30yr yields were higher by c.6bps. The 2s30s spread widened by c.5bos at settlement, and the 5s30s wider by 2bps – the steepening leaves 2s30s and 5s30s more or less flat for the week. US Treasury announced that it will next week sell $32bln in 2yr notes, $35bln in 5yr notes, $29bln in 7yr and $17bln in a 2yr FRN. The US Treasury sold $16bln of 5-year TIPS, stopping through slightly. While it is difficult to compare internals given the large time frame between the previous 5-year TIPS auction, the internals were good, with dealer takedown the beneath recent averages, while cover was slightly firmer. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 10 ticks lower at 119-26+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 19 April 2018: Trump not target of Mueller probe, says Dep. AG
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks down, USD up, treasuries down, oil down
* REAR-VIEW: Soft UK retail sales, BOE’s Carney dovish, mixed Philly Fed, weekly claims in line.
* AHEAD: Japan CPI (overnight), FOMC voter Mester (after market), Canada CPI and retail sales (Fri), OPEC+ (Fri), FOMC voter Williams and Fed’s Evans (Fri), BOE’s Saunders (Fri)., Eurozone consumer confidence (Fri).

 

*TRADE WARS: in late trade, a US official said US Treasury weighing emergency powers on China. Much of the trade talk came from Canada today: PM Trudeau noted the Mexican and US elections are putting pressure on NAFTA talks, and Foreign Minister Freeland said NAFTA negotiators are currently in intensified engagement. Elsewhere, German FinMin Scholz said that Germany and France are not seeking a special trade deal with the US, though are seeking permanent exemptions on US steel tariffs.  

* CENTRAL BANK SPEAK: BOE Governor Carney said we should prepare for a number of interest rate hikes over the next few years, though was unspecific on timing. Traders seemed focused on the line that the MPC is conscious that there are other meetings over the course of this year (a hint that the May hike is not a dead-cert), and Carney noted wage growth and productivity require improvements, also acknowledging mixed data this week, which was likely the reason for the dovish price reaction. BoE’s Cunliffe (Dove) expressed warning on trade and noted tensions could spill over into other areas. Fed’s Brainard (voter, dove) said inflation is well anchored bet there are some signs of imbalances. Fed’s Quarles (Voter, Neutral) sees no reason to intervene in the debate between banks and the gun industry. In Europe, ECB “sources” reported that the central bank was not likely to raise rates before the end of 2019, and QE will end in 2018; the view saw little price action given there was little fresh insight.

* DATA: US Philly Fed data for April saw the headline rise slightly, against a consensus expectation of a decline, but sub-indices were mixed. The Easter effect may have weighed on new orders, analysts said, though the employment component rose. Weekly jobless claims data was more or less in line with expectations, falling 1k in the week to 232k. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that claims have been above trend in recent weeks, but this is likely due to the timing of Easter, and that impact will fade soon. In the UK, this week’s soft inflation data was followed-up by a weak retail sales report, which was likely hit on weather effects. Analysts still expect a May hike from the BOE (though probability has fallen to above 80% from around 90% at the beginning of the week), but there seems to be a growing view that a second BOE hike in 2018 may be under threat.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.59% at 2693, NDX -0.86% at 6774, DJI -0.34% at 24664  SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY):  -0.36%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -3.14%, ENERGY (XLE): +0.14%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.53%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.81%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.29%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.07%, TECH (XLK): -1.13%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.78%, UTLITIES (XLU): -0.09%. Further, Comcast (CMCSA) sent a bid for Fox’s Assets, higher than Disney’s (DIS) offer, however CNCB notes the conditions were not favourable and were said to raise regulatory concerns. Elsewhere, reports In NY Post stated that the US DoJ is said to be close to clearing the $6.6bln Sinclair (SBGI) & Tribune Media (TRCO) merger. Semiconductor names were in focus today following poor outlook from Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC) which expects Q2 revenue to be between $7.8bln and $7.9bln, roughly $1bln lower than wall street estimates. This had a knock-on effect to other chipmakers with the SOX spending the session in the red and chip names all at the bottom of the NDX. Also, reports just before the close yesterday that Facebook (FB) is said to create a team to create semiconductors also hampered some names like Intel (INTC). Elsewhere in stock specifics earnings dominated yet again, with Snap-On (SNA), American Express (AXP) Bank of New York Mellon among top performers in the SPX following strong earnings report. On the flipside Phillip Morris (PM) getting smoked following a miss on revenues and a larger decline than expected in cigarette and heated tobacco shipments, this rolled on to Altria (MO) also closing among the worst SPX performers.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle down 18 cents at USD 68.29/bbl, Brent futures settle up 30 cents at USD 73.78/bbl. Oil bulls continue to push crude to multi-year highs, and as UBS points out, bulls now have the ball in their court after the recent EIA, IEA and OPEC reports hint that demand growth has begun to outpace supply growth; additionally, geopolitical inject a further upside bias – and traders are alert to the Trump administration potentially re-applying sanctions on Iran (US has until 12/May to make a decision). In crude specific news, ahead of tomorrow’s meeting between OPEC+ policymakers, sources reported that OPEC+ panel has found that the oil glut has been virtually eliminated, largely due to the supply cut deal. However, the monitoring committee noted that developed nations’ inventories stood at 12mln bbls above the five-year average, some 340mln bbls above the average in January 2017, highlighting the work that the cartel still needs to do. Elsewhere, Norway reported prelim oil production in March declined to 1.519mln BPD (Prev. 1.564mln). Other OPEC sources reported that in meetings there was no talk from Saudi Arabia to target a $100/bbl price, and that such a target would be a “danger” to the market. Another OPEC source report that Iraq was still cheating on its quota. Elsewhere, Genscape was said to have reported Cushing stocks are forecast to build by 700k in the week (change vs 13/April).

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 10 ticks lower at 119-26+. The yield curve bear-flattened on Thursday with most of the action seen in the long-end, where 30yr yields were higher by c.6bps. subject: Bond bears firmly back in the driving seat
content: It’s classic case of passing the baton, as the latest leg down in fixed appears to be US Treasury led in contrast to Bunds calling the tune earlier. Moreover, 10 year T-note futures are threatening a clear break of tech and psychological support at 120-00, at 119-28, and with the equivalent yield up to 2.90+%. Consequently, the German equivalent is now looking at the next downside chart level, 158.36, at 158.33, and 158.05 looms on the radar/0.66% cash. Gilts down to 121.51 (-73 ticks) and edging closer to 121.44/1.50%.

content: Contacts indicate that the 1.2000 historic (or 3+ year old to be precise) mark has been revisited in Eur/Chf, but the buyer will have to be patient in terms of making money given the almost immediate reversal in the cross to a circa 1.1965 low in a matter of seconds. However, bond bulls and jobbers looking more a counter-trend move in debt could turn a profit given a bounce in Bunds from 158.45 to 158.55 or so amidst hourly tech studies suggesting oversold conditions and short covering. There may be potential for a lot more retracement (40-120 ticks by past standards), but buyers are likely to be wary of the current negative tone.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Equity markets mostly flat as macro effects subside, focus turns toward earnings
  • UK Retail sales falls below expectations pulling cable below the 1.42 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed and a slew of central bank speakers

 

19th April 2018

  • Equity markets mostly flat as macro effects subside, focus turns toward earnings
  • UK Retail sales falls below expectations pulling cable below the 1.42 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed and a slew of central bank speakers

ASIA

Asian stocks were higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus and the energy sector outperformed after crude rallied over 3% to its highest since 2014. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was lifted by commodity names as miners outperformed amid strength in metals prices, which also boosted BHP shares despite a disappointing quarterly iron ore production update. Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was also led higher by metal stocks and in tandem with a weaker currency, while Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) conformed to the commodity-led gains with the blue-chip energy stocks in Hong Kong cheering the higher oil prices and with sentiment also helped by another firm liquidity operation by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as upside in riskier assets sapped safe-haven demand, and with price action also kept tame by mixed 20yr auction results which showed reduced demand but higher accepted prices.

PBoC injected CNY 190bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2832 (Prev. 6.2817)

US President Trump said will shrink the US trade deficit with Japan and hopefully a balance will be reached, while he later stated that they are negotiating a one-on-one trade deal with Japan. There were also comments from Japanese PM Abe that he agreed with US President Trump to begin discussions on fair, free and reciprocal trade, while he also commented that TPP is the best trade deal for both Japan and US. (Newswires)

Australian Employment Change (Mar) 4.9k vs. Exp. 20.0k (Prev. 17.5k, Rev. -6.3k).

Australian Full Time Employment (Mar) -19.9k (Prev. 64.9k, Rev. 20.1k)

Australian Unemployment Rate (Mar) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.6%, Rev. 5.5%)

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Q1) 7 (Prev. 6,. Rev. 7)

New Zealand CPI QQ (Q1) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.1%).

New Zealand CPI YY (Q1) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.6%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed’s Quarles (Voter, Neutral) says does not view current yield curve flattening as a signal for a recession. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (Non-voter, Hawkish) suggests US lacks buffers for next downturn. (Newswires)

RBNZ Governor Orr says expects very benign inflation ahead, adds doggedly determined to aim for inflation at 2%. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK Retail Sales MM (Mar) -1.2% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. 0.8%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel MM (Mar) -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. 0.6%, Rev. 0.4%)

UK Retail Sales YY (Mar) 1.1% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.5%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel YY (Mar) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.1%, Rev. 1.2%)

 

EQUITIES

Equities have seen the narrative subside from macro effects and move toward individual stock news as the Eurostoxx remains roughly flat (-0.05%), with FTSE as the outperforming index (+0.2% due to FX effects) and SMI (-0.07%) the underperformer amid domestic earnings. Large cap stocks news are as follows, with ABB beating EBITDA expectations (+4.9%) pushing industrials to be the sector outperformer whilst Novartis (-1.9%) have dragged down healthcare. Nestle (+0.3%) falling in line with expectations, Unilever (-1.9%) who were disappointing and Pernod Ricard (-0.9%) announcing an earnings beat. In the M&A scope, Merck (+0.5%) confirmed their decision to offload their consumer unit to P&G for around EUR 3.4bln

FX

DXY

The index remains contained in a relatively tight range around 89.500, and mostly firmer for choice, but narrowly mixed vs G10 counterparts. The commodity currencies are gleaning support from underlying price gains, while comments from China’s SAFE contending that the Dollar may decline further as other global economies catch up has also aided EMs to recoup more recent losses.

GBP

Sterling’s April winning streak has hit another potential obstacle in the shape of much weaker than expected UK retail sales data, and Cable has fallen back below the 1.4200 handle as a result to re-test and marginally breach lows seen in wake of Wednesday’s CPI miss. Market contacts report sell-stops through 1.4170, but there has been limited follow-through so far with Gbp/Usd finding buyers around 1.4160 and Eur/Gbp capped just ahead of 0.8740.

AUD

A marginal outperformer as broad risk appetite and extended rallies in oil/metals more than offset a disappointing Aussie jobs report overnight, but Aud/Usd is still finding the atmosphere above 0.7800 tough to reside in, with some key chart resistance levels also keeping the pair in check (200 DMA at 0.7817 and a 0.7831 Fib.

EUR/JPY

Both sticking rigidly to recent ranges, with key chart levels restraining price action alongside hefty and some mega option expiries. Eur/Usd looks bid below 1.2350 and offered on treks above 1.2400, while Usd/Jpy has been supported just under 107.00 and mostly resistant around 107.50-55.

NZD/CAD/CHF

All still on a weaker footing, the Kiwi hovering just above 0.7300 vs the Usd after mixed NZ inflation data, the Loonie still reflecting on cautious/dovish BoC policy guidance with Usd/Cad above 1.2600 and Franc feeling the effects of Russian asset repatriation with Usd/Chf edging back towards 0.9700 and Eur/Chf just pips away from 1.2000.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts only partially pared losses on the 3rd UK data miss in a row, with the DMO auction probably capping the rebound (though in the event the tap was well received) , and the 10 year bond actually posting a fresh low for the day in recent trade at 121.67 (-57 ticks) before finding some traction again. Meanwhile, Bunds have been as low as 158.45 (-60 ticks) and supply issues seem to have pushed French OATs and Spanish Bonos deeper into negative territory amidst mixed auction results. USTs also erring towards the path of least resistance again as fixed income in general remains in bear (steepening) clutches.

COMMODITIES

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.8%) and Brent (+1%) remain close to highs that were last seen in 2014 amid reports yesterday Saudi Arabia would favour crude prices to rise US 80/bbl, or even USD 100/bbl. The upside is also followed the DoE inventory report which mirrored the API release and showed drawdowns across all product components. In the metals bloc, gold is trading softer amid pressure from a slightly firmer dollar, whilst Dalian iron ore rose almost 7% overnight, and Nickel soared 9% to a three-year high amid Russian sanction by the US on major Russian aluminium producer Rusal. Nickel has now risen over 16% in the last two sessions, whilst the Shanghai Futures Exchange cut intra-day transaction fees for nickel futures contracts for May to CNY 6 from current CNY 30.

OPEC and Non-OPEC committee are said to have seen stockpiles nearly cleared. (Newswires)

Both sticking rigidly to recent ranges, with key chart levels restraining price action alongside hefty and some mega option expiries. Eur/Usd looks bid below 1.2350 and offered on treks above 1.2400, while Usd/Jpy has been supported just under 107.00 and mostly resistant around 107.50-55.

NZD/CAD/CHF

All still on a weaker footing, the Kiwi hovering just above 0.7300 vs the Usd after mixed NZ inflation data, the Loonie still reflecting on cautious/dovish BoC policy guidance with Usd/Cad above 1.2600 and Franc feeling the effects of Russian asset repatriation with Usd/Chf edging back towards 0.9700 and Eur/Chf just pips away from 1.2000.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts only partially pared losses on the 3rd UK data miss in a row, with the DMO auction probably capping the rebound (though in the event the tap was well received) , and the 10 year bond actually posting a fresh low for the day in recent trade at 121.67 (-57 ticks) before finding some traction again. Meanwhile, Bunds have been as low as 158.48 (-57 ticks) and supply issues seem to have pushed French OATs and Spanish Bonos deeper into negative territory amidst mixed auction results. USTs also erring towards the path of least resistance again as fixed income in general remains in bear (steepening) clutches.

COMMODITIES

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.8%) and Brent (+1%) remain close to highs that were last seen in 2014 amid reports yesterday Saudi Arabia would favour crude prices to rise US 80/bbl, or even USD 100/bbl. The upside is also followed the DoE inventory report which mirrored the API release and showed drawdowns across all product components. In the metals bloc, gold is trading softer amid pressure from a slightly firmer dollar, whilst Dalian iron ore rose almost 7% overnight, and Nickel soared 9% to a three-year high amid Russian sanction by the US on major Russian aluminium producer Rusal. Nickel has now risen over 16% in the last two sessions, whilst the Shanghai Futures Exchange cut intra-day transaction fees for nickel futures contracts for May to CNY 6 from current CNY 30.

Bunds: back below 159.00 and eyeing upside yield breakout
content: A more concerted and certainly earlier foray below the big figure after an initial print at 159.03 and fleeting uptick to 159.04 vs Wednesday’s 159.05 close. Better volumes than of late behind the push lower to 158.89 so far, and the corresponding 10 year yield is nudging above 0.55%, tracking its US Treasury counterpart that has firmed to circa 2.87%, albeit with an ongoing lag. The core German bond may also be prone to more spread positioning vs the periphery as Italian BTPs continue to outperform, although Spanish Bonos are trading defensively ahead of heavy supply and this could be keeping OATs on the backfoot given multi-tranche auctions shortly after. Debt sales aside, Eurozone current account data and comments from ECB President Draghi and Coeure to come, while from a technical perspective market contacts highlight 159.93 as a potentially key level on a closing basis due to daily chart analysis and yearly trend-line resistance.

subject: BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from Spain, France, UK, and US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: Spanish EUR 4-5bln 0.45% 2022, 1.40% 2028 and 2.35% 2033 Bond Auction

IFR:

- By way of a benchmark 10yr Spain/Germany has gone bid again since the widest level on April 12

- Outright 10yr Spain is easing back after a 1.28% high recently

- Recent Spanish auctions have been slightly tepid affairs with respect to the total size sold but bidding has been solid

- Competing French supply afterwards shouldn’t be a problem unless the market sells off aggressively between now and then

In terms of historical data:

0.45% 2022 prev. b/c 1.45 and average yield 0.294%

1.40% 2028 prev. b/c 1.51 and average yield 1.148%

2.35% 2033 prev. b/c 1.65 and average yield 1.875%

Bids are submitted by 0930BST and results are published shortly after

AUCTION PREVIEW: French EUR 6-7bln 0% 2021, 0% 2023, 1.75% 2024 Bond Auction

IFR:

- OATs have rallied to rich end of range of last three months, middle of range from last Dec

- 10s have outperformed within French curve, leading to modest concession

- OATs have outperformed on cross-markets basis, but 11/24s have lagged a little

- 11/24 OATs have lagged against swaps

-  Big redemptions should help take down incoming supply

In terms of historical data:

0% 2021 prev. b/c 2.13 and average yield -0.24%

0% 2023 prev. b/c 4.15 and average yield 0.23%

1.75% 2024 prev. b/c 2.03 and average yield 0.18%

Bids are submitted by 0950BST and results are published shortly after

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: UK  GBP 2.5bln 1.625% 2028 Gilt Auction

IFR:

- Lack of natural concession given since outright yields on the line are around 8bp lower since the launch at 1.508%

- Expectations for the tap rest on relative value

- There is around 5bp of value to be had on an asset swap basis

In terms of historical data:

Prev. b/c 0.2bps, average yield 1.58% and b/c of 2.62

Bids are submitted by 1030BST and results are published shortly after

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 16bln 5y TIPS

The last 5-year TIPS auction took place in December 2017 when the US Treasury sold USD 14bln of 5y TIPS with a B/C of 2.78x and yield of 0.370%. Indirects took 71.7% of the issuance, directs 12.2%, leaving dealers with 16.1%. The auction prior to the last in August 2017 was covered 2.41x with a high yield of 0.117%. 

UBS are positive on the 5y TIPS issuance: “we think 5y real yields are getting attractive as they are above median long-run neutral real rate,” the bank said, “As such, we expect 5y TIPS beta to nominals to decline going forward and the issue benefits from trade uncertainty.” SocGen are also constructive on the auction as they think current inflation perceptions supported by energy prices and prints, coupled with positive inflation carry and multi-year highs in real yields should help.

Looking forward, the Treasury is expected to increase TIPS supply with most foreseeing an increase in 5y TIPS issuance after the TBAC recommendation in February. However, this is not expected until October this year, announced at the August quarterly refunding announcement.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Nestle and Novartis
content:
19th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks were higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus and the energy sector outperformed after crude rallied over 3% to its highest since 2014. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names as miners outperformed amid strength in metals prices, which also boosted BHP shares despite a disappointing quarterly iron ore production update. Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also led higher by metal stocks and in tandem with a weaker currency, while Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to the commodity-led gains with the blue-chip energy stocks in Hong Kong cheering the higher oil prices and with sentiment also helped by another firm liquidity operation by the PBoC.

FTSE

BHP (BLT LN) – Q3 iron ore production 67.0mln tons vs. Exp. 69.0mln tons, Prev. 62.0mln tons Y/Y, 9-month total iron ore production ended March 2018 rose 2% to a record 175mln tons. Co. cuts guidance for FY 18 iron ore output to between 236mln-238mln tons from 239mln-243mln tons. Co. nickel operations are reportedly being bolstered by demand for EV in China, according to reports. (AFR)

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – Aberdeen Standard Investments says the Co. was right to walk away from a merger with its rival Intu “rather than face the embarrassment of failing to win shareholder support”. (Times)

Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) - Patrick Bousquet-Chavanne, the marketing boss of Marks & Spencer is the latest senior executive to leave the retailer, announcing his departure on Twitter yesterday. (Times)

GKN (GKN LN) – Co.’s merger with Melrose (MRO LN) could be approved as early as next week by the UK government. (FT)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. receives approval for TAGRISSO for treatment of EGFR-mutated non-small cell lung cancer. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Bovis Homes (BVS LN) – Co. is misleading buyers and “deliberately” delaying essential repairs to poorly built homes, an investigation by The Times has found. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

HSBC (HSBA LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

KERRY GROUP (KYGA LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

HAMMERSON (HMSO LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM UNDERPEFORM AT JEFFERIES

POLYMETAL (POLY LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – A Supervisory board is discussing another potential executive reshuffle at the bank, including the potential departure of COO Kim Hammonds, according to people familiar with the matter. (WSJ)

Merck (MRK GY) - Co. confirm their decision to offload their consumer unit to P&G (PG) for around EUR 3.4bln. (Newswires)  

BROKER MOVES

FRAPORT (FRA GY) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

CAC

Accor (AC FP) – Accorhotels reports Q1 revenue +9.5% LFL at EUR 663mln, Q1 revenue EUR 633mln vs. Prev. EUR 629mln. Accorhotels CFO says group is confident and optimistic over Q2. (Newswires)

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) - The co. reports Q3 sales of EUR 1.977bln vs. exp. EUR 1.96bln, confirms 2017/18 guidance for underlying operating profit at top end of range at 6%. Additionally says they are to distribute and interim cash dividend of EUR 1.01 on July 6th. (Newswires)

Publicis (PUB FP) – Q1 net revenues +1.60% vs. Exp. 0.94% on organic basis to EUR 2.082bln. Co. confirms full-year 2018 targets for a stronger year-on-year growth.

Schneider Electric (SU FP) - The co. reports Q1 revenue of EUR 5.80bln vs. exp. EUR 5.67bln, impact of foreign exchange flows negative at EUR -453mln or -8.4%. FY objectives confirmed. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

ADP (ADP FP) - The co. has acquired control of Airport International Group, concessionary of Queen Alia International Airport in Amman, Jordan. (Newswires)

Gecina (GFC FP) – Q1 gross rental income at EUR 168.5mln vs. Prev. 119.6mln. Co. confirms 2018 guidance. (Newswires)

SMI

Nestle (NESN SW) - The co. reported Q1 sales of CHF 21.3bln vs exp. CHF 21.4bln, organic growth of 2.8% vs. exp. 2.5%, Adds the co. is on track for its 2018 guidance and 2020 mid-term targets. (Newswires)

Novartis (NOVN SW) - The co. reports Q1 sales of USD 12.694bln vs exp. USD 12.258bln, net income of USD 2.982bln vs. exp. USD 2.982bln, operating income USD 3.340bln vs. exp. USD 3.331bln, and EPS of USD 1.28 vs. exp. USD 1.25. The co. confirms 2018 outlook. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks were higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus
content:
• Asian stocks were higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus
  • UK House of Lords voted 348 - 225 for Brexit amendment that would keep UK in the Customs Union with the EU as expected
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK retail sales, US weekly jobs, Philly Fed and a slew of central bank speakers

ASIA

Asian stocks were higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus and the energy sector outperformed after crude rallied over 3% to its highest since 2014. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names as miners outperformed amid strength in metals prices, which also boosted BHP shares despite a disappointing quarterly iron ore production update. Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also led higher by metal stocks and in tandem with a weaker currency, while Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to the commodity-led gains with the blue-chip energy stocks in Hong Kong cheering the higher oil prices and with sentiment also helped by another firm liquidity operation by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as upside in riskier assets sapped safe-haven demand, and with price action also kept tame by mixed 20yr auction results which showed reduced demand but higher accepted prices.

PBoC injected CNY 190bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2832 (Prev. 6.2817)

China MOFCOM said it is to implement temporary anti-dumping measures on halogenated butyl rubber imports from US, EU and Singapore. Furthermore, MOFCOM stated it is reviewing Qualcomm and NXP deal and that it may have a negative impact on the market. (Newswires)

HKMA Deputy Chief Executive Lee said operation in banking system has been smooth and that no large-scale shorting of HKD is seen, while Lee further added that HKD 50bln outflow isn't much. (Newswires)

US President Trump said will shrink the US trade deficit with Japan and hopefully a balance will be reached, while he later stated that they are negotiating a one-on-one trade deal with Japan. There were also comments from Japanese PM Abe that he agreed with US President Trump to begin discussions on fair, free and reciprocal trade, while he also commented that TPP is the best trade deal for both Japan and US. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK House of Lords voted 348 - 225 for Brexit amendment that would keep UK in the Customs Union with the EU as expected, which was against PM May’s wishes and sends the amended EU withdrawal bill back to the House of Commons. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau told UK PM May their countries could move quickly towards trade deal post-Brexit. (Newswires)

Italy’s’ S5M leader Di Maio said they are not willing to govern with centre right coalition and that they are only ready to form with League. (Newswires)
FX

The DXY was range-bound overnight which kept its major counterparts restrained with GBP/USD around the 1.4200 level following yesterday’s softer than expected CPI data, while CAD also found very little redemption from the post-BoC pressure after Governor Poloz said interest rates may need to remain below the neutral range. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was underpinned as the positive sentiment spurred JPY outflows, while antipodeans were choppy and initially data-determined with AUD pressured by abysmal Employment numbers and with NZD subdued after CPI data beat expectations Q/Q but also showed a substantial Y/Y slowdown from the prior quarter. However, both AUD and NZD later pared losses and took strength from the upside in commodities and stronger CNY.

Australian Employment Change (Mar) 4.9k vs. Exp. 20.0k (Prev. 17.5k, Rev. -6.3k). (Newswires)
Australian Full Time Employment (Mar) -19.9k (Prev. 64.9k, Rev. 20.1k)
Australian Unemployment Rate (Mar) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.6%, Rev. 5.5%)

New Zealand CPI QQ (Q1) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
New Zealand CPI YY (Q1) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.6%)

COMMODITIES 

Gains were seen across the commodities in which WTI crude futures remained firm after the prior day’s reports that Saudi Arabia is said to favour oil price of USD 80/bbl and even USD 100/bbl, while the upside also followed the DoE inventory report which mirrored the API release and showed drawdowns across all product components. Elsewhere, gold and copper prices were higher alongside broad strength in the complex in which Chinese metal prices gained around 3%-5% at the open and with LME aluminium up over 4% to its highest since July 2011.
GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump reportedly told Russian officials not to expect any new sanctions. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated that Secretary of State nominee Pompeo got along very well with North Korean leader Kim. However, President Trump later stated US will continue campaign of maximum pressure until North Korea denuclearizes and that he will not meet with North Korean leader Kim if he thinks it is unlikely to be fruitful, while he added that he would leave the meeting if it is not fruitful. (Newswires)

US

The yield curve bear-flattened during the session, with most of the action concentrated in the belly of the curve, where yields on 5s and 7s yield rose by c.5bps, pushing 5s30s under 30bps. There were fresh cyclical highs for the 2yr yield which sent the US/German 2yr spread above 300bps, the widest since 1989. The flattening of the curve has not gone unnoticed by policy makers, Fed’s Bullard again warned the risks of a yield curve inversion could be seen within 6 months and said the Fed should have discussions on the subject. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 13+ lower at 120-04+.

Fed Beige Book said the economy continues to expand at modest-to-moderate pace, while it added that employment growth continues, labour markets were tight and that shortages of skills were reported. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names as miners outperformed amid strength in metals prices, which also boosted BHP shares despite a disappointing quarterly iron ore production update. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also led higher by metal stocks and in tandem with a weaker currency, while Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to the commodity-led gains with the blue-chip energy stocks in Hong Kong cheering the higher oil prices and with sentiment also helped by another firm liquidity operation by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as upside in riskier assets sapped safe-haven demand, and with price action also kept tame by mixed 20yr auction results which showed reduced demand but higher accepted prices. ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Commodity strength provides lift for Asia-Pac stocks
content:
Asia stocks are higher across the board following the mostly positive lead from Wall St, where earnings remained in focus and the energy sector outperformed after crude rallied over 3% to its highest since 2014. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was lifted by commodity names with miners outperforming amid strength in metals prices, which has also boosted BHP shares despite a disappointing quarterly iron production update. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) is also led higher by metal stocks and in tandem with a weaker currency, while Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) conform to the commodity-led gains with the blue-chip energy stocks in Hong Kong cheering the higher oil prices and with sentiment also helped by another firm liquidity operation by the PBoC.

In FX markets, the DXY was marginally higher which hampered its major counterparts and pulled GBP/USD back below the 1.4200 handle following yesterday’s softer than expected CPI data, while CAD also found little redemption from the post-BoC policy meeting pressure after Governor Poloz said interest rates may need to remain below the neutral range. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was underpinned as the sentiment spurred JPY outflows, while antipodeans were dictated by releases with AUD pressured by abysmal Employment numbers and with NZD subdued after CPI data beat expectations Q/Q but also showed a substantial Y/Y slowdown from the prior quarter.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with demand lacking amid the upside in riskier assets, while participants also await a 20yr auction later.
